history.content: It will only count if you NP the class.
Yes. But it won't count towards anything else (GPA, etc.) unless you NP the class.

children.subject: As a Berkeley-wide policy, if you pass a course, you cannot retake it. (Technically you can still enroll in it, but it won't count towards anything at all.)
correction above: you can retake if you get a D+ or worse, and anything in the D range is still considered passing.

Actually, I think if you P the class, you can take it again to make it count toward the major requirement. 

It just doesn't count toward GPA or antthing.

history.content:
You may repeat a course only if you received a grade of D+, D, D-, F, or no pass (NP).

If you earned a grade of D+, D, D-, or F, and have taken the course only once:

  • You must take the course for a letter grade.
  • Both grades will show on your transcript, but only your most recent grade will be calculated into your GPA.

Note: If you have repeated more than 12 units of credit, the above does not apply.

If you earned an NP, and have taken the course only once before, you may:

  • Repeat the course for either a letter grade, if allowed in the course
    OR
  • Take the course a pass/no pass basis

12-Unit Repetition Limit

  • Repeat the course for either a letter grade, if allowed in the course.
    • On a pass/no pass basis.
    • If you repeat courses in which you received a D+, D, D–, or F, the units are counted only once and only the most recently earned grades and grade points are used for the first 12 units repeated.
    • If you repeat more than 12 units, your grade-point average is based on all grades assigned and total units attempted.

http://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades

children.subject:
The latter.

You can only retake a class once, regardless of how you do the second time.

(Although based on your specific example, in case you weren't aware, I'll also point to the CS-department-specific policy on retaking courses for major declaration purposes at @3105).

I'm not too sure what the 12-unit repetition limit mean.

is it 

#1. for a 4-unit class, you can repeat it for 3 times. and if you repeat a 4th time, the GPA will be using all the grades assigned.

OR

#2 takes into account of all your past repeated different classes. let's say you've repeated Math1A, Math1B, CS61A. then you're at the "12-unit limit". so if you're trying to repeat CS61B, the GPA will be using both semester grades?

history.content: Hi, I'm an LSCS major, and I was wondering if it is possible to take a CS Upper Div for a PNP in one semester, and then take it for a letter grade second time around the next semester? Would the letter grade I receive taking the class the second time be counted towards CS upper div requirement?
history.subject: PNP a CS Upper Div and then take it for Letter Grade
